Class LightSensor

                    +--eecs.jago.element.StandardSensor
                          |
                          +--eecs.jago.element.LightSensor
All Implemented Interfaces:
Attachment, Collidable, Mobile, Realism, RobotSensors, java.lang.Runnable, SensorState, Visible
public class LightSensor
extends StandardSensor

A sensor, similar in function to the blue light sensor that is included with a Lego Mindstorms robot kit.

Since a LightSensor implements the Realism interface, it will function differently depending on the realism setting.

IDEALISTIC mode: The LightSensor does not actually detect anything; it is only a means to convey the information. It requires that the host to which it is attached notify it of a new value.

The only true functionality in this mode is that it will reset itself after a very small amount of time with no new "reading" from the host.

Because of this link, the host is fully responsible for determining when the LightSensor "detects" something; in essence, using a LightSensor in this mode allows a host to detect light anywhere, based on it's implementation (the standard implementation is to base it on a collision, see StandardRobot.handleCollision(eecs.jago.element.Collidable) for one such implementation).

  Readings: In IDEALISTIC mode, the reading will always be exactly what is specified by the host, since the LightSensor is not actually generating the reading. When no reading has been offered by the host, the LightSensor will revert to the SensorState.OFF state (even though OFF really has no meaning for a light sensor).

REALISTIC Mode: In this mode, the sensor will continuously detect the level of reflection from the simulation. It will detect everything that was drawn before it, so readings will be given for both the normal background, and for any objects that have been added (see DisplayManager to determine the order of presentation). In this mode, there is no OFF state, and readings will be much less predictable. The sensor averages the intensity of the group of pixels where it will be drawn, so a single pixel will be sufficient to generate a completely different, and unreliable reading.

If the host attempts to set the value of the sensor in this mode, the call will merely be ignored--no messages or exceptions will be generated to indicate that the setting did not occur.

This mode much more accurately represents the Lego light sensor, and the difficulty in using the sensor for much more than bi-level differentiation (it is nearly impossible to accurately detect "color" using the Lego sensor).

setValue

public void setValue(int value)
Deprecated. This is no longer required or desired. As of v6.2.3 of the simulation, the sensor is fully responsible for its own setting

Sets the value of the sensor. This call is only valid if the sensor is operating in IDEALISTIC mode (the set is ignored in REALISTIC mode). In IDEALISTIC mode: The value of the sensor is set by the host, and the sensor will maintain that state for approximately 160ms (3 updates) unless the host sets the value again (either to the same or a different color).

Overrides:
setValue in class StandardSensor
Parameters:
value - DOCUMENT ME!

handleCollision

public void handleCollision(Collidable collider)
Determines the outcome of a collision. If in IDEALISTIC mode, this is the only way that Reflective elements will be detected by the light sensor. This method also passes the collision to its parent (see StandardSensor.handleCollision(eecs.jago.element.Collidable)) so the host will be notified of a collision.

Specified by:
handleCollision in interface Collidable
Overrides:
handleCollision in class StandardSensor
Parameters:
collider - The Collidable element that the LightSensor made contact with.

runTaskStep

protected void runTaskStep()
Updates the sensor at each step in the simulation. In REALISTIC mode, no action is performed (updates are performed when the sensor is drawn when in REALISTIC mode).

Overrides:
runTaskStep in class MobileElement
